fields.title: the silver bell; or the crystal palace
fields.history_note:
The centre board sheet is missing, however, the game appears to be very similar to GRANDMAMA'S NEW GAME OF NATURAL HISTORY and it is probable that the board was in the same style but with fewer compartments.
see also E.1786-1954.
fields.historical_context_note:
Rewards: receipt of counters
Forfeits: Each player to pay one counter to all of the courts - lettered on 2 cards.
payment of counters
No. of Players: any
Equipment required: 20 cards showing views in and of the Crystal Palace and lettered Bell at the top; 18 cards showing various historical courts in the exhibition with titles; 9 cards bearing the names of the various historical courts decorated with scrolled floral motifs; 5 showing a bell surrounded by green drapery; 2 with titles of the game; 2 with the forfeit line
instruction leaflet incorporating a list of other publications

Rules:
THE SILVER BELL OR THE CRYSTAL PALACE A GAME:

Any number of persons may play at this amusing game.
Let counters be distributed in the usual manner to each player.  (This means that an agreed number, say 20, are given to each player at the start of the game).
The dealer must put one counter into each compartment on the board, which is to be placed in the centre of the table; he then may deal round some cards to each player, reserving about half the pack.  The cards are to be placed before each player with the faces downwards.  Any player looking at his cards to forfeit two counters to the centre compartment in the board.  The player to the left of the dealer may then turn up a card, and the next players continue playing in succession, until the GAME CARD is turned up, which ends the game; but it will frequently happen that several deals will be required before this card is turned up:-  The deal to be taken in rotation by the players.

It will be perceived that nine courts are delineated on the board, to which there are 18 corresponding cards; the players of these cards must each pay one counter, placing it on the same counrt on the board.  The nine cards with shields inscribed with the names of the court, entitle the players to take all the counters on the corresponding compart - ments on the board as they are turned up.  The players of each of the twenty views of the Crystal Palace with BELL printed on them are to pay 2 counters to the centre compartment on the board as turned up.  The five BELL CARDS are to be then used:- when a player turns one of them up, he may hold it until another player turns one up, when the first player must relinguish it and give it to the last player and so on until all the 5 Bell Cards are turned up when, of course, there can be no further change.  When the Game Card is turned up, the holder of a Bell Card or Cards, if they are turned up, may take all the counters on the board.--If the CRYSTAL PALACE CARD is turned up before the Game Card, the player may take all the counters on the nine court divisions, leaving the counters in the Silver Bell compartment.--Should the Game Card be turned up before any of the Bell Cards have been played, the player of it may then take the counters in the centre division only.  It will be observed in other cases, that the player turning up the Game Card must not take the counters on the board, but the fortunate holder of one or more of the 5 Bell Cards, obtains this prize when the Game Card is turned up.  The use of the other cards will be seen by the printing on them.
